title: SB 1073
content: The people of California enact the following. Section 17052 of the Revenue and Taxation Code is amended to allow an earned income tax credit against the "net tax" for taxable years starting January 1, 2015. The credit amount is determined based on Section 32 of the Internal Revenue Code, adjusted by a factor specified in the annual Budget Act. The credit is only applicable when resources are allocated for oversight and auditing by the Franchise Tax Board. The earned income tax credit is only available when resources are allocated for oversight by the Franchise Tax Board. The credit percentage and phaseout percentage vary based on the number of qualifying children. The earned income amount and phaseout amount also vary depending on the number of qualifying children. Joint returns are not applicable for this credit. The earned income tax credit amounts vary based on the number of qualifying children: $3,290 for no qualifying children, $4,940 for 1 qualifying child, and $6,935 for 2 or more qualifying children. Certain sections of the Internal Revenue Code are modified for this credit, including adjustments to the earned income amount and place of abode. The Internal Revenue Code is modified for the earned income tax credit, with changes to the place of abode and income amount. Excess credit can be used to offset other tax liabilities and refunded to the taxpayer. The Franchise Tax Board can establish rules for this section, refunds are treated like federal earned income refunds for benefit eligibility, and exemptions are granted for implementing the credit for the 2015 taxable year. The Franchise Tax Board will incorporate the scope, costs, and schedule changes for the California Earned Income Tax Credit in its next Special Project Report. The purpose of the credit is to reduce poverty among working families and individuals, and the Board will annually report on the number of tax returns claiming the credit, individuals represented, average credit amount, and distribution of credits by dependents and income ranges. The Franchise Tax Board will provide a written report on the California Earned Income Tax Credit, including details on the average credit amount, distribution by dependents and income ranges, and the impact on lifting families out of deep poverty. The tax credit will be known as the California Earned Income Tax Credit. The tax credit allowed by this section shall be known as the California Earned Income Tax Credit and applies to taxable years beginning on or after January 1, 2016.
